{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox military person |name=Emile Frank Verlaine Dechaineux |birth_date= {{birth date|df=yes|1902|10|3}} |death_date= {{death date and age|df=yes|1944|10|21|1902|10|3}} |image=Emile Dechaineux AWM 106692.jpg |caption=Captain Emile Dechaineux, c. 1943. |birth_place = [[Launceston, Tasmania|Launceston]], [[Tasmania]],
[[Australia]] |death_place = At sea, in the [[Leyte Gulf]], [[Pacific Ocean]] |placeofburial= At sea, in the [[Leyte Gulf]], [[Pacific Ocean]] |nickname= |residence = |nationality = [[Australian]] |allegiance= {{flagicon|Australia}} Australia |serviceyears=1919–1944 |rank=[[Captain (naval)|Captain]] |branch=[[Royal Australian Navy]] |commands=[[HMAS Warramunga (I44)|HMAS ''Warramunga'']];
[[HMAS Australia (1927)|HMAS ''Australia'']] |unit= |battles= |awards=[[Distinguished Service Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Service Cross]]
[[Legion of Merit|Officer of the Legion of Merit]] (United States) |relations= }} '''Emile Frank Verlaine Dechaineux''', [[Distinguished Service Cross (United Kingdom)|DSC]] (3 October 1902 – 21 October 1944) was an [[Australia]]n mariner who reached the rank of [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] in the [[Royal Australian Navy]] during [[World War II]]. He was killed by a [[Empire of Japan|Japanese]] aircraft in what is believed to have been the first ever ''[[kamikaze]]'' attack, in the lead-up to the [[Battle of Leyte Gulf]]. ==Biography== [[File:HMAS Australia bridge.jpg|300px|thumb|Dechaineux (second right) on the bridge of [[HMAS Australia (1927)|HMAS ''Australia'']] in September 1944.]] Dechaineux was born in [[Launceston, Tasmania]], to a [[Belgium|Belgian]]-born father, Florent Vincent Emile Lucien Dechaineux, and an Australian mother.[http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/dechaineux-emile-frank-verlaine-9940 Australian Dictionary of Biography] He entered the [[Royal Australian Naval College]], [[Jervis Bay]] at the age of 14, graduated three years later, and was promoted to [[Midshipman]] in 1920. In the first half of the 20th century, the RAN worked very closely with the British [[Royal Navy]] (RN), frequently exchanging personnel. Dechaineux spent much of the 1920s training with the RN as a torpedo officer and naval air observer. In September 1932 Dechaineux achieved the rank of Lieutenant Commander. In 1935 he was appointed Squadron Torpedo Officer, on board [[HMAS Canberra (1927)|HMAS ''Canberra'']]. The following year he married Mary Harbottle. In 1937, Dechaineux returned to the UK to attend the [[Royal Naval College, Greenwich|Royal Naval College]] and in June he was promoted to [[Commander]]. At the outbreak of [[World War II]], Dechaineux was attached to the RN Tactical and Minesweeping divisions until April 1940. Then, as the commander of the [[destroyer]] [[HMS Vivacious|HMS ''Vivacious'']], he made five trips to assist [[Operation Dynamo]], the evacuation of Dunkirk. On 26 May the ship was allocated to Dynamo. At first, deployed from Dover, on 27 May the ship patrolled the beaches off Dunkirk, providing general anti-aircraft cover and protecting against fast E-boat attacks while scores of vessels crossed the mercifully semi-calm Channel in evacuation. The pleasure steamer ''Mona’s Isle'', for example, now fitted out as an armed boarding vessel, was amongst the many. But her machineguns were no match for the attacking aircraft and occasional ship of the enemy: she was bombed as she reached the open sea outside Britain, and 40 on board were killed. This was the new and dangerous world of Dechaineux in action for the first time. The next day the destroyer made two trips from Dunkirk to Dover, bringing out 326 men in the first trip and 359 in the second; one can only imagine the crowding of every interior space and her weather deck by so many men. Two days later another 537 men were safely landed in the British port. On 31 May the vessel came under fire from shore batteries off Bray and sustained 15 casualties. Dechaineux received a minor wound to his forehead and a piece of shrapnel tore the back of his trousers In a letter to his wife he remarked “I am very grateful that the ship was heading away from the gunfire, rather than towards it!” On 1 June another 427 men were brought back to Dover. On 3 June the destroyer was directed to take part in Operation OK, which sank blockships, to provide a temporary wharfage point, in Dunkirk Harbour. Vivacious safely brought the crews of these ships back across the Channel. Altogether the destroyer brought out a total of 1,649 passengers from Dunkirk during five voyages. The evacuation lasted nine days, and safely brought hundreds of thousands of men back to Britain. Four years later, many would return for the D-Day landings. Dechaineux had proved his worth during his baptism of fire, not only by commanding the ship through battle, but also through the effective leadership of his men. He was destined for greater things. On 25 September 1940 he was given command of the brand new Hunt-class escort destroyer, HMS Eglington. After working up to satisfactory operational capability in Scapa Flow – where the ship and her captain were assessed by RN experts – the last months of the year were spent on North Sea convoy escort duties, as was 1941, although on 4 October the ship carried out a brief search for a German destroyer reported minelaying off South Foreland.Lewis, Tom. [[The Submarine Six.]] Adelaide: Avonmore Books, 2010. In 1941, he was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Service Cross]].[[London Gazette]]: [http://www.gazettes-online.co.uk/ViewPDF.aspx?pdf=35204&geotype=London&gpn=3745&type=ArchivedSupplementPage&all=&exact=&atleast=&similar= (Supplement) no. 35204, page 3745], 27 June 1941 Dechaineux returned to Australia later in 1941, as Director of Operations at the Navy Office in Melbourne. In June 1943, following the outbreak of [[Pacific War|war with Japan]], he was given command of the tactical (destroyer) component of RAN-[[United States Navy|US Navy]] [[Task Force 74]]. From his immediate command, [[HMAS Warramunga (I44)|HMAS ''Warramunga'']], Dechaineux commanded operations in waters around Australia and [[New Guinea]], including support for amphibious landings, such as those in the [[Admiralty Islands]]. He was promoted to [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] on 31 December 1943.[[London Gazette]]: [http://www.gazettes-online.co.uk/ViewPDF.aspx?pdf=36326&geotype=London&gpn=229&type=ArchivedIssuePage&all=&exact=&atleast=&similar= (Supplement) no. 36326, page 229], 11 January 1944 On 9 March 1944, Dechaineux was given command of the [[heavy cruiser]] [[HMAS Australia (1927)|HMAS ''Australia'']], the flagship of both the RAN and Task Force 74, under the overall force commander Commodore [[John Augustine Collins|John Collins]]. The ''Australia'' supported Allied landings at [[Jayapura|Hollandia]] in [[Dutch New Guinea]] and on the islands of [[Biak]], [[Noemfoor]] and [[Morotai]]. On 21 October 1944, HMAS ''Australia'' was supporting [[Battle of Leyte|the landings in Leyte Gulf]]. Off [[Leyte (island)|Leyte Island]], gunners from HMAS ''Australia'' and [[HMAS Shropshire|HMAS ''Shropshire'']] fired at and hit a Japanese aircraft. Initially, the plane flew away from the ships, but it subsequently turned and dived into ''Australia''. The plane struck the superstructure of the ''Australia'' above the [[bridge (ship)|bridge]]. Although the 200 kg (440 pound) bomb carried by the plane failed to explode, burning fuel and debris were spewed over a large area. Dechaineux was disembowelled by shrapnel and died a few hours later. He was buried at sea that night. Another 30 crew members died as a result of the attack; among the wounded was Commodore Collins. The US government posthumously appointed Dechaineux an Officer of the [[Legion of Merit]].{{cite web|url=http://adbonline.anu.edu.au/biogs/A130675b.htm|title=Dechaineux, Emile Frank Verlaine (1902 - 1944) |work=Australian Dictionary of Biography|publisher=Australian National University|accessdate=22 February 2010}} In 1990 the Australian government announced that a new [[Collins class submarine]] would be named [[HMAS Dechaineux|HMAS ''Dechaineux'']] in his memory. It was launched in 1998 in the presence of Dechaineux's widow, Mary Purbrick, and his son, former RAN Commodore Peter Dechaineux. ==Honours and awards== Captain Emile Dechaineux was decorated with the following honours:
[[File:Distinguished Service Cross (UK) ribbon.png|100px]] [[File:1939-45 Star.png|100px]] [[File:AtlanticStarRibbon2.jpg|100px]] [[File:Pacific Star.gif|100px]] [[File:War Medal 39-45 BAR MID.png|100px]] [[File:Australian Service Medal 1939-45 ribbon.jpg|100px]] [[File:Us legion of merit officer rib.jpg|100px]]

{{for|the Japanese Meiji era British-born educator and sportsman|Frederick William Strange (rower)}} '''Frederick William Strange''' (September 9, 1844 – June 5, 1897) was an [[England|English]]-born physician, surgeon and political figure in [[Ontario]], Canada. He represented [[York North]] in the [[House of Commons of Canada]] from 1878 to 1882 as a [[Liberal-Conservative]] member.
He was the son of Thomas Strange of [[Berkshire]] and studied medicine at [[Liverpool]] and [[University College London|University College]] in [[London]]. Strange came to Ontario in 1869. A long-time militia medical officer, he served as a deputy surgeon general for the Canadian militia from 1893 to 1896 and was [[coroner]] for [[York County, Ontario|York County]]. Strange was an unsuccessful candidate for a seat in the House of Commons in 1896. He died a year later at the age of 52.
The community of [[Strange, Ontario|Strange]] was named in his honour after he secured a post office for the community in 1880.

{{Infobox company |name=Game Freak Inc. |logo=Game Freak logo.png |type=[[Privately held company|Private]] |founded={{start date and age|1989|04|26}} |location=[[Tokyo]], Japan |key_people={{plainlist| *[[Junichi Masuda]] *[[Shigeki Morimoto]] }} |industry=[[Video game industry|Video game]] |products=''[[Pokémon (video game series)|Pokémon]]'' series |revenue= |founders = [[Satoshi Tajiri]]
[[Ken Sugimori]] |operating_income= |net_income= |num_employees=143 (2018){{cite web|url=http://www.gamefreak.co.jp/company/about.html|script-title=ja:会社概要|publisher=Game Freak Inc.|accessdate=June 13, 2016|language=Japanese}} |parent= |subsid= |homepage={{URL|http://www.gamefreak.co.jp/}} |footnotes= }} [[File:Game Freak magazine.jpg|thumb|The covers of several issues of ''Game Freak'' magazine]] {{nihongo|'''Game Freak Inc.'''|株式会社ゲームフリーク|[[Kabushiki gaisha]] Gēmu Furīku|lead=yes}} is a Japanese [[video game developer]], best known as the primary developer of the ''[[Pokémon (video game series)|Pokémon]]'' series of [[role-playing video game]]s published by [[Nintendo]]. ==History== [[File:The Story of Satoshi Tajiri.webm|thumb|An animated history of how Satoshi Tajiri came to conceive ''Pokémon'']] Predating the video game company, ''Game Freak'' was a self-published [[Video game journalism|video game magazine]] created by [[Satoshi Tajiri]] and [[Ken Sugimori]] in the 1980s. Tajiri wrote and edited the text and Sugimori illustrated. Tajiri also used "Game Freak" as his pen name when he wrote as a freelance writer to publications such as ''Family Computer Magazine'' and ''[[Famitsu|Famicom Tsūshin]]''.{{cite journal|journal=Family Computer Magazine|script-title=ja:ぼくたちゲーセン野郎|language=Japanese|author=[[Satoshi Tajiri]]|url=https://twitter.com/chou_nosuke/status/606052702246666241|date=1989-01-06|pages=114–115|accessdate=2015-11-29}}{{cite journal|journal=[[Famitsu|Biweekly Famicom Journal]]|script-title=ja:ビデヲゲーム通信|language=Japanese|author=[[Satoshi Tajiri]]|url=https://twitter.com/chou_nosuke/status/612229058202505216/photo/1|date=1986-08-01|accessdate=2015-11-29}} On April 26, 1989, Tajiri and Sugimori started a video game development company with the same name.{{cite news| url=https://www.wired.com/gamelife/2010/04/pokemon-creators-fanzine-fetches-high-price/ | work=Wired | first=Chris | last=Kohler | title=Pokémon Creators' Fanzine Fetches High Price | date=2010-04-19}}{{cite web|title=COLUMN: 'Game Mag Weaseling': Just Checking In|url=http://www.gamesetwatch.com/2008/04/column_game_mag_weaseling_just.php|publisher=GameSetWatch}}{{cite news|author= Previous post Next post |url=https://www.wired.com/gamelife/2010/04/pokemon-creators-fanzine-fetches-high-price/ |title=Pokémon Creators' Fanzine Fetches High Price | GameLife |publisher=Wired.com |date= 2010-04-19|accessdate=2010-11-16}}{{cite web|last=Gifford |first=Kevin |url=http://www.gamesetwatch.com/2008/04/column_game_mag_weaseling_just.php |title=COLUMN: 'Game Mag Weaseling': Just Checking In |publisher=GameSetWatch |date=2008-04-07 |accessdate=2010-11-16}} One of Game Freak's first games was the [[Nintendo Entertainment System]] action and puzzle game ''Quinty'', which was released in North America as ''[[Mendel Palace]]''. Its most popular series, ''[[Pokémon (video game series)|Pokémon]]''—the [[Romanization of Japanese|romanized]] [[portmanteau]] of the Japanese brand {{nihongo|''Pocket Monsters''|ポケットモンスター|'''Poke'''tto '''Mon'''sutā}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gamingtarget.com/article.php?artid=6531 |title=The Pokemon Series Pokedex |accessdate=February 28, 2007 |last=Swider |first=Matt |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |year= |month= |work=Gaming Target |publisher=Gaming Target |pages= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote=}}—is published and distributed respectively by [[The Pokémon Company]] and [[Nintendo]] worldwide. In October 2015, Game Freak bought Koa Games, a mobile development company.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamnesia.com/news/pokemon-developer-game-freak-has-purchased-a-mobile-game-development-compan|title=Pokémon Developer Game Freak Has Purchased a Mobile Game Development Company|publisher=}} ==Gameography== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center;" width="auto" !Year!!Title!!Publisher!!Platform(s) |- |1989||''Quinty''JP, ''[[Mendel Palace]]''NA||[[Namco]]JP, [[Hudson Soft]]NA||[[NES]] |- | rowspan="2" |1991||''[[Smart Ball]]''||[[Sony Music Entertainment Japan]]||[[SNES]] |- |''[[Yoshi (video game)|Yoshi]]''||[[Nintendo]]||NES, [[Game Boy]] |- |1992||''[[Magical Taluluto|Magical Tarurūto-kun]]''||[[Sega]]||[[Mega Drive]] |- |1993||''[[Mario & Wario]]''||Nintendo||SNES |- | rowspan="2" |1994||''[[Nontan|Nontan to Issho: Kuru-Kuru Puzzle]]''||[[Victor Interactive Software]]||Game Boy, Super Famicom |- |''[[Pulseman]]''||Sega||Mega Drive |- | rowspan="2" |1996||[[Pokémon Red and Blue|''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue'']]||Nintendo||Game Boy |- |''Bazaar de Gosāru no Game de Gosāru''||[[NEC]]||[[PC Engine]] |- |1997||''Bushi Seiryūden: Futari no Yūsha''||[[T&E Soft]]||Super Famicom |- | rowspan="2" |1998||''[[Game Boy Camera]]''|| rowspan="3" |Nintendo|| rowspan="2" |Game Boy |- |''[[Pokémon Yellow]]'' |- | rowspan="2" |1999||[[Pokémon Gold and Silver|''Pokémon Gold'' and ''Silver'']]||[[Game Boy Color]] |- |''Click Medic''||Sony Music Entertainment Japan||[[PlayStation]] |- |2000||''[[Pokémon Crystal]]''||Nintendo||Game Boy Color |- |2002||[[Pokémon Ruby and Sapphire|''Pokémon Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'']] | rowspan="3" |Nintendo

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Ghosts Can't Do It | image = Ghosts Can't Do It FilmPoster.jpeg | alt = | caption = Release poster | director = [[John Derek]] | producer = [[Bo Derek]]
[[Chandran Rutnam]] | writer = John Derek | starring = {{Plainlist| * Bo Derek * [[Anthony Quinn]] * [[Don Murray (actor)|Don Murray]] * [[Donald Trump]] }} | music = {{Plainlist| * Junior Homrich * Randall Tico }} | cinematography = John Derek | editing = John Derek | production companies = {{Plainlist| * crackAjack Movie Company * Epic Productions * Sarliu/Diamant }} | distributor = [[Triumph Releasing]] | released = {{Film date|1989|10|17|foreign video premiere|1990|06|01}} | runtime = 90 minutes | country = United States | language = English }} '''''Ghosts Can't Do It''''' is a 1989 American [[Romance film|romantic]] [[Crime film|crime]] [[Fantasy film|fantasy]] [[comedy film]] written and directed by [[John Derek]], and starring [[Bo Derek]] and [[Anthony Quinn]].[https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/19688/Ghosts-Can-t-Do-It/overview "Ghosts Can't Do It (1990)"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved January 23, 2015. The film was shot in 1989 and released on [[home video]] the same year in Australia. In the United States, the film received a theatrical release in 1990. It was poorly reviewed by critics, and won the 1990 [[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Picture]], tying with ''[[The Adventures of Ford Fairlane]]''. In a cameo, it features future American President [[Donald Trump]], receiving a Raspberry Award for Worst Supporting Actor. ==Plot== Scott and Kate are happily married, despite their 30-year age difference. After Scott suffers a heart attack and is unable to make love, he commits [[suicide]] and becomes a ghost that only Kate can see and speak with. To make it possible for Scott to return as a human, they conjure up a plan to have a young man drown, so that Scott can take his body. ==Cast== * [[Bo Derek]] as Katie Scott (née O'Dare) * [[Anthony Quinn]] as Scott * Leo Damian as Fausto * [[Julie Newmar]] as Angel * [[Don Murray (actor)|Don Murray]] as Winston * [[Donald Trump]] as himself ==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Award ! Category ! Subject ! Result |- |[[Stinkers Bad Movie Awards|Stinkers Bad Movie Award]] |Worst Picture{{Cite web|url=http://theenvelope.latimes.com/extras/lostmind/year/1990/1990st.htm |title=1990 13th Hastings Bad Cinema Society Stinkers Awards |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |work=[[Stinkers Bad Movie Awards]] |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061017173658/http://theenvelope.latimes.com/extras/lostmind/year/1990/1990st.htm |archivedate=October 17, 2006 }} |rowspan=3|[[Bo Derek]] |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=8|[[Golden Raspberry Awards]] |[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Picture|Worst Picture]] |{{won}} |- |[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Actress|Worst Actress]] |{{won}} |- |[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Director|Worst Director]] |rowspan=2|[[John Derek]] |{{won}} |- |[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Screenplay|Worst Screenplay]] |{{nom}} |- |[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Supporting Actress|Worst Supporting Actress]] |[[Julie Newmar]] |{{nom}} |- |[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Supporting Actor|Worst Supporting Actor]] |rowspan=2|[[Donald Trump]] |{{won}} |- |rowspan=2|[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst New Star|Worst New Star]] |{{nom}} |- |Leo Damian |{{nom}} |- |} == Critical reception == The reception was extremely negative. {{cite news|last1=Corasaniti|first1=Nick|title=Donald Trump would be a nominee unlike anyone else, ever - The Boston Globe|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/politics/2016/05/04/donald-trump-nominee-unlike-anyone-else-ever/mKhRc8FsdQplzm68gMl7zL/story.html|accessdate=December 6, 2016|work=BostonGlobe.com|date=May 5, 2016}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0099656|Ghosts Can't Do It}} {{Razzie Award for Worst Picture}} {{John Derek}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ghosts Can't Do It}} [[Category:1989 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:1980s crime films]] [[Category:1980s fantasy films]] [[Category:1980s romantic comedy films]] [[Category:American criminal comedy films]] [[Category:American fantasy-comedy films]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:American romantic comedy films]] [[Category:Films about death]] [[Category:Films about suicide]] [[Category:Films shot in Hong Kong]] [[Category:Films shot in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Films shot in the Maldives]] [[Category:Films shot in Wyoming]] [[Category:Ghost films]] [[Category:Fiction about spirit possession]] [[Category:Films directed by John Derek]]

{{Infobox animal | name = Jean, the Vitagraph Dog | image = Jean-Vitagraph-Portrait-1911.jpg | image_size = | caption = Jean, the Vitagraph Dog | birth_name = | othername = | species = [[Dog]] | breed = [[Scotch Collie|Scotch]] [[Collie]] | gender = Female | birth_date = 1902 | birth_place = [[Eastport, Maine]] | death_date = 1916 | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = | occupation = Dog actor | employer = [[Vitagraph Studios]] | role = | years_active = 1909–1916 | known = | tricks = | awards = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | owner = [[Laurence Trimble]] | parents = | children = | weight = | height = | appearance = | namedafter = | website = }} '''Jean''', also known as the '''Vitagraph Dog''' (1902–1916), was a female collie that starred in [[silent films]]. Owned and guided by director [[Laurence Trimble]], she was the first canine to have a leading role in motion pictures. Jean was with [[Vitagraph Studios]] from 1909, and in 1913 went with Trimble to England to work with [[Florence Turner]] in her own independent film company. ==Life and career== [[File:Jean-Vitagraph-1912.jpg|thumb|140px|left|Jean in 1912]] Around 1908, [[Maine]] resident and writer [[Laurence Trimble]] sold an animal story to a New York [[magazine]].{{Rp|139}} In 1909 Trimble visited [[Vitagraph Studios]] in New York while doing research for a series of articles called "How Movies Are Made". As he chatted with the sole assistant working under [[Rollin S. Sturgeon]], head of the scenario department, he learned that a story of special interest to producer [[Albert E. Smith (producer)|Albert E. Smith]] had been set aside because it required a dog that could act—not simply do tricks, but to behave naturally on command. Trimble scanned the script and said he could train any dog to do what was needed.{{Rp|44}} Trimble asked if there were any dogs around, and was told about a stray that hid in the garage and came out only to snatch scraps left by members of the crew. Trimble spent an hour coaxing the frightened dog out of hiding, and another half-hour winning his confidence. Smith was brought in and saw the dog perform the action the script required. "Your dog is wonderful," Smith told Trimble, "but he's too small"—explaining that it would be impossible to see a small dog in [[medium shot]]s, one of Vitagraph's filmmaking innovations. "Oh, he isn't my dog," Trimble replied. He told Smith that the little dog was a stray, suggested that he take him home as a pet, and said, "Tomorrow I'll bring you the right dog for the picture." The next morning he arrived with his dog, a tri-color [[Scotch Collie]] named Jean.{{cite book|last=Trimble |first=Marian Blackton |editor1-last=Slide |editor1-first=Anthony |date=1985 |title=J. Stuart Blackton: A Personal Biography by His Daughter |location=Metuchen, New Jersey |publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield|Scarecrow Press]] |isbn=9780810817654}}{{Rp|44–46}} "Jean, the Vitagraph Dog" became the first canine to have a leading role in motion pictures.{{cite book |last=Slide |first=Anthony |authorlink=Anthony Slide |date=1976 |title=The Big V: A History of the Vitagraph Company |url= |location=Metuchen, N.J. |publisher=Scarecrow Press |isbn=9780810809673}}{{Rp|139}} [[File:Jean-the-Match-Maker-1910.jpg|thumb|left|Jean, [[Florence Turner]] and [[Mary Fuller]] in ''[[Jean the Match-Maker]]'' (1910), a film that survives]] [[File:Playmates.webm|thumb|left|thumbtime=1:09|''[[c:File:Playmates.webm|Playmates]]'' (1912), a film that survives]] "Jean was equal in popularity to Vitagraph's human stars, [[Florence Turner]] and [[Maurice Costello]]," wrote film historian [[Anthony Slide]].{{Rp|139}} Jean was soon starring in her own films, all directed by Trimble. One-reelers and two-reelers with titles such as ''[[Jean and the Calico Doll]]'', ''Jean and the Waif'' and ''Jean Goes Fishing'' were made by Trimble as their troupe filmed along the coastline in his native Maine.{{cite magazine |last=Gallo |first=Joe |date=March 2000 |title=Flashback: New England Director Larry Trimble |url=http://www.imaginenews.com/Archive/2000/MAR_2000/Text/FEAT06.htm |magazine=Imagine Magazine |location= |publisher= |access-date=2018-02-23 }} Trimble became a leading director at Vitagraph, directing most of the films made by Turner and [[John Bunny]], as well as those made by Jean.{{Rp|139}} Actress [[Helen Hayes]] recalled in a 1931 interview with ''The New York Times'' that as an eight-year-old she had roles in two of the 1910 films. "I had long curls and they let me play the juvenile lead in two pictures in support of Jean, the collie," Hayes said. "Jean was the most famous dog of the day and I was very thrilled."{{cite news |last= |first= |date=March 15, 1931 |title=Miss Hayes and Films |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D04E3DB1F30E633A25756C1A9659C946094D6CF |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |location= |access-date=2015-11-28 }} In December 1912, Jean gave birth to six puppies{{Rp|139}}—two male and four female—and was the subject of the Vitagraph documentary short film, ''Jean and Her Family'' (1913).{{cite news |last= |first= |date=April 21, 1913 |title=Amusements at the Dixie |newspaper=[[The Bryan-College Station Eagle|The Bryan Daily Eagle]] }} In March 1913, Trimble and Jean left Vitagraph and accompanied Florence Turner to England, where she formed her own company, Turner Films.{{Rp|36}} Trimble and his canine star returned to the United States in 1916. Jean died later that year,{{Rp|139}}{{cite news |last=Brownlow |first=Kevin |authorlink=Kevin Brownlow |date=May 31, 1999 |title=Obituary: Jan Zilliacus |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/obituary-jan-zilliacus-1097376.html |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |access-date=2016-07-29 }} at age 14.{{cite magazine |last=Trimble |first=Larry |date=February 1930 |title=About Me and My Friends |magazine=[[The American Boy (magazine)|The American Boy]] |volume=104 |issue=2 |page=49 }} Trimble tried to launch the career of a successor, Shep the Vitagraph Dog, without success.{{Rp|140}} He then discovered and worked with another dog star, the famed [[Strongheart]].{{cite news |last= |first= |date=February 10, 1954 |title=Laurence Trimble Dies |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B05E3DB1638E23BBC4852DFB466838F649EDE |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=2015-11-28 }}{{cite book|title=An Encyclopedic Dictionary of Women in Early American Films: 1895-1930|last=Lowe|first=Denise|publisher=[[Routledge]]|year=2014|isbn=9781317718963|at=J: Jean|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=68e2AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA1947-IA41}} The four films he made with Strongheart won Trimble a special place in film history, but in later years he would say that, in the qualities of spirit and intelligence, Jean was the best of all his dogs.{{Rp|46}} Trimble eventually retired from filmmaking and trained animals exclusively. His special interest was training [[guide dog]]s for the blind.{{cite book |last=Taves |first=Brian |date=2005 |title=Talbot Mundy, Philosopher of Adventure: A Critical Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UlGQBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA290&lpg=PA290&dq=Seeing+Eye+Larry+Trimble&source=bl&ots=FB3gDhIB7J&sig=OUURBUAVJM37aC9Z3_lHLtCgG3c&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjo0a-ci8XOAhXMsh4KHee7COkQ6AEIUDAI#v=onepage&q=Seeing%20Eye%20Larry%20Trimble&f=false |location=Jefferson, North Carolina |publisher=McFarland |page=290 |isbn=9780786422340}} ==Films== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 260 | image1 =Jean-Playmates-1912.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 =Jean and [[Florence Foley]] in ''Playmates'' (1912) | image2 =Church-Across-the-Way-1912-3.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 =[[Helene Costello]] and Jean in ''The Church Across the Way'' (1912) | image3 =Jean's-Evidence-1913.jpg | alt3 = | caption3 =Jean and [[Florence Turner]] in ''Jean's Evidence'' (1913) }} Jean's films are [[lost film]]s, with the exception of ''[[Jean the Match-Maker]]'' (1910), ''Jean Rescues'' (1911), in [[paper print]] at the [[Library of Congress]],{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}, and ''Playmates'' (1912). {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 1910 | ''[[Jean and the Calico Doll]]'' | Jean | Short film{{cite web |url=http://www.afi.com/members/catalog/SearchResult.aspx?s=&TBL=PN&Type=CA&ID=2219 |title=Jean |website=[[AFI Catalog of Feature Films]] |publisher=[[American Film Institute]] |access-date=2015-11-28}}
Film debut of [[Helen Hayes]]{{cite book |last1=Murphy |first1=Donn B. |last2=Moore |first2=Stephen |date=1993 |title=Helen Hayes: A Bio-Bibliography |url= |location=Westport, Connecticut |publisher=Greenwood Press |page=153 |isbn=9780313277931 }} |- | 1910 | ''[[Jean the Match-Maker]]'' | Jean | Short film{{cite web |url=http://www.filmpreservation.org/preserved-films/screening-room/jean-the-matchmaker-1910 |title=Jean the Match-Maker |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=Preserved Films |publisher=[[National Film Preservation Foundation]] |access-date=2015-11-28 }} |- | 1910 | ''Jean Goes Foraging'' | Jean | Short film |- | 1910 | ''Jean Goes Fishing'' | Jean | Short film |- | 1910 | ''{{sortname|A|Tin-Type Romance}}'' | | Short film |- | 1910 | ''Jean and the Waif'' | Jean | Short film |- | 1910 | ''Where the Winds Blow'' | | Short film |- | 1910 | ''Her Mother's Wedding Gown'' | | Short film |- | 1911 | ''Jean Rescues'' | Jean | Short film{{cite web |url=http://explore.bfi.org.uk/4ce2bb455a467 |title=Jean |publisher=British Film Institute |access-date=2015-11-28}} |- | 1911 | revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/66.24.219.173|66.24.219.173]] ([[User talk:66.24.219.173|talk]]): Please [[WP:V|cite sources]]. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox criminal |name = Lena Baker |image_name = Lena Baker.jpg |image_size = |image_caption = Lena Baker's February 23, 1945 mugshot |birth_date = {{birth date|1900|06|08}} |birth_place = [[Cuthbert, Georgia]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1945|03|05|1900|06|08}} |death_place = [[Reidsville, Georgia]] |conviction = [[Capital murder]] |conviction_penalty = Death by electrocution |conviction_status = Executed |occupation = Maid |children = 3 }}
[[File:Lena Baker headstone.jpg|thumb|right|220px|The Lena Baker headstone in Mt. Vernon Baptist Church cemetery, in Cuthbert, GA]] '''Lena Baker''' (June 8, 1900 – March 5, 1945)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bishop.house.gov/media-center/congressional-record-statements/in-honor-of-lena-baker-posthumously|title=In Honor of Lena Baker (Posthumously)|date=January 3, 2011|work=Congressman Sanford Bishop|access-date=October 20, 2017|language=en}}</ref> was an [[African American]] maid in [[Cuthbert, Georgia]] who was convicted of [[capital murder]] of her white employer, Ernest Knight. She was executed by the [[Georgia (U.S. state)|state of Georgia]] in 1945.<ref name="guardian"/> Baker was the only woman in Georgia to be executed by electrocution. <ref name="npr">{{cite web |last=Lohr |first=Kathy |title=Ga. Woman Pardoned 60 Years After Her Execution |work=National Public Radio |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4818124 |accessdate=December 10, 2008}}</ref><ref name="guardian"/>
The slaying and execution came during a decades-long period of state suppression of civil rights of black citizens in Georgia by the white-dominated society. It had [[Disfranchisement after Reconstruction era|disenfranchised blacks]] since the turn of the century, and imposed legal racial segregation and second-class status. At the time of the trial, a local newspaper reported that Baker was held as a "slave woman" by Knight, and that she shot him in self-defense during a struggle.<ref name="phillips"/>
In 2005, sixty years after her execution, the state of Georgia granted Baker a full and unconditional [[pardon]]. A biography was published about Baker in 2001, and it was adapted for the feature film ''[[The Lena Baker Story]]'' (2008), chronicling the events of her life, trial, and execution.
==Early life== Lena Baker was born June 8, 1900, to a family of [[sharecroppers]] and raised near [[Cuthbert, Georgia]]. Her family, which included three siblings, moved to the county seat when she was a child. As a youth, she and her siblings all worked as farm laborers; she chopped cotton for a farmer named J.A. Cox.<ref name="crime2">{{cite web |first=Seamus |last=McGraw |title=Missing Mamma: The Lena Baker Story: The Pursuit of Justice - truTV dramatization |work=The Crime Library |url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/not_guilty/lena_baker/2.html |accessdate=December 10, 2008}}</ref>
==Later years== By the 1940s, Baker was the mother of three children and worked as a maid to support her family. In 1944, Baker started working for Ernest Knight, an older white man who had broken his leg. He owned a [[gristmill]] and, after they started a sexual relationship, he would keep her there imprisoned for days at a time in "near slavery."<ref name="phillips">[http://www.blackcommentator.com/40/40_guest_commentary.html Guest Commentary: Lela Bond Phillips, "The Lena Baker Story: Execution in a small town"], ''The Black Commentator,'' May 2003, accessed June 24, 2016</ref> Knight's son and townspeople disliked their relationship, and tried to end it through threatening Baker.<ref name="guardian"/> One night an argument between the two ensued, during which Knight threatened Baker with an iron bar. As she tried to escape, they struggled over his pistol and she shot and killed him. She immediately reported the incident and said she had acted in [[self-defense]].
==Trial and execution== Lena Baker was charged with [[capital murder]] and stood trial on August 14, 1944. The trial was presided over by Judge William "Two Gun" Worrill, who kept a pair of pistols in view on his judicial bench.<ref name="crime2" /> At her trial, Baker testified that Knight forced her to go with him on that Saturday evening of April 29. The town disliked their sexual relationship and the county sheriff had warned her to stay away from Knight, or risk being sent to jail. But she was afraid of Knight's physical abuse; he had forced relations on her. His son had also beat her on another occasion, warning her to stay away from his father.<ref name="phillips"/> Baker said she got away from Knight that night and slept in the woods. As she returned to Cuthbert the next morning, Knight cornered her, taking her to the gristmill and locking her in. When Knight returned, Baker told him she was leaving. According to Baker, they "tussled over the pistol," after he threatened her with an iron bar.<ref name="npr"/> She immediately reported it to J.A. Cox, the county coroner who had previously employed her.
The all-white, all-male jury rejected Baker's plea of self-defense and convicted her of capital murder by the end of the first day of the trial.<ref name="crime2" /> This charge carried an automatic death sentence. In addition to the legal racial segregation imposed by the white-dominated Georgia legislature, it had [[Disfranchisement after Reconstruction era|disenfranchised most blacks]] since the turn of the century, which disqualified them from jury service. After Baker's court-appointed counsel, W.L. Ferguson, filed an appeal, he dropped Baker as a client.<ref name="crime2" />
Governor [[Ellis Arnall]] granted Baker a 60-day reprieve so that the Board of Pardons and Parole could review the case, but in January 1945 it denied Baker clemency.<ref name="case"/> She was transferred to [[Georgia State Prison]] at Reidsville on February 23, 1945.<ref name="case">{{cite web |title=Lena Baker Case |work=History and Archaeology >> Progressive Era to World War II, 1900-1945 |url=http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?id=h-2917 |publisher=The New Georgia Encyclopedia |accessdate=December 10, 2008}}</ref>
{{quote|text=What I done, I did in self-defense, or I would have been killed myself. Where I was I could not overcome it. God has forgiven me. I have nothing against anyone. I picked cotton for Mr. Pritchett, and he has been good to me. I am ready to go. I am one in the number. I am ready to meet my God. I have a very strong conscience.|author=Baker's last words<ref name="crime2" />}}
Baker was executed on March 5, 1945.<ref name="guardian"/> She was buried in an unmarked grave behind Mount Vernon Baptist Church, where she had sung in the choir.
==Posthumous recognition and legacy== In 1998, members of the congregation arranged for a simple headstone for her grave.<ref name="case"/> That year two articles were published about her case.<ref>Woolner, Ann. "Condemned in a Day," ''Fulton County Daily Report,'' March 9, 1998; Woolner, Ann. "Lena Baker: Postscript," ''Fulton County Daily Report,'' March 16, 1998</ref>
In 2003, descendants of Baker's family began to mark the anniversary of her death and Mother's Day at her graveside. That year Baker's grandnephew, Roosevelt Curry, requested an official pardon from the state, aided by the Georgia-based prison advocacy group, Prison and Jail Project.
In 2005, the Parole Board granted Baker a full and unconditional pardon.<ref name="guardian"/><ref name="case"/><ref name="crime2" /> Commentators have suggested that in 1945, the Board of Pardons and Parole could have lowered her charge to voluntary [[manslaughter]], which would have carried an average 15-year sentence and saved her life.<ref name="guardian">{{cite web |first=Gary |last=Younge |title=Pardon for maid executed in 1945 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/aug/17/usa.garyyounge1 |work=The Guardian |date=August 17, 2005 |accessdate=December 10, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Executed US maid to be pardoned |date=August 16, 2005 |work=[[BBC News]] |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/4155732.stm |accessdate=August 10, 2008}}</ref>
==Representation in other media== In 2001 Lela Bond Phillips, a professor at [[Andrew College]], published a biography, ''The Lena Baker Story'' ({{ISBN|978-1930897076}}) This was adapted as a [[The Lena Baker Story|feature film of the same name]], released in 2008.
==See also== *[[List of wrongful convictions in the United States]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *Phillips, Lela Bond. ''The Lena Baker Story''. Atlanta: Wings Publishers, 2001.
==External links== *{{Find a Grave|11544277}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Baker, Lena}} [[Category:1900 births]] [[Category:1945 deaths]] [[Category:1944 murders in the United States]] [[Category:20th-century executions of American people]] [[Category:20th-century executions by Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:American female criminals]] [[Category:American female murderers]] [[Category:American murderers]] [[Category:American people convicted of murder]] [[Category:Executed African-American people]] [[Category:Executed American women]] [[Category:Executed people from Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:People executed by Georgia (U.S. state) by electric chair]] [[Category:People executed for murder]] [[Category:People who have received posthumous pardons]] [[Category:Recipients of American pardons]] [[Category:Women sentenced to death]] [[Category:Wrongful convictions]] [[Category:People from Cuthbert, Georgia]]

revision.text:
{{one source|date=August 2018}} '''Leonardo Marini''' (1509 in [[Chios]] – 11 June 1573 in [[Rome]]) was a [[theologian]] and [[Italy|Italian]] [[archbishop]] of the [[Dominican Order]] of [[Catholic Church]].
==Biography== Born on the island of [[Chios]], in the [[Aegean Sea]], to a noble [[Genoa|Genoese]] family. He entered the [[Dominican Order]] and studied theology.
Marini failed to be bishop of [[Perugia]] when Pope Paul III died before he could elect him, but his successor, [[Pope Julius III]] appointed him the administrator of the diocese of [[Mantua]] and bishop of [[Diocese of Laodicensis in Phrygia]] (March 5, 1550).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/09669a.htm|title=CATHOLIC ENCYCLOPEDIA: Marina|website=www.newadvent.org|access-date=2017-11-27}}</ref>
He also served as [[papal diplomat]] to [[Emperor Charles V]], and in 1560 [[Pope Pius IV]] appointed him bishop of [[Lanciano]] (and archbishop in 1562). He was [[papal legate]] to the [[Council of Trent]]. After being transferred to [[Alba]] (1566), appointed [[apostolic visitor]] to twenty-five dioceses of Italy.
He collaborated on the formation of the [[Roman Catechism]] and was a member of the [[Roman Breviary]] reform commission (1568) and of the [[Roman Missal]] (1570). On behalf of Pius IV, he reviewed the rules and constitutions of the Clerics Regular of St. Paul ([[Barnabites]]).
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist|30em}}

[[File:BNMsFr2643FroissartFol97vExecHughDespenser.jpg|right|thumb|220px|The execution of [[Hugh Despenser the Younger]], as pictured in the [[Froissart of Louis of Gruuthuse (BnF Fr 2643-6)|Froissart of Louis of Gruuthuse]]]] To be [[hanged, drawn and quartered]] was a penalty in England and the [[United Kingdom]] for several crimes, but mainly for [[high treason]]. This method was abolished in England in 1870.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Date executed !! Name !! Notes |- |1305-08-23|| [[William Wallace]] || Treason in the [[Wars of Scottish Independence]] |- | 1323 ||[[Andrew Harclay, 1st Earl of Carlisle]]|| Treason in the [[Wars of Scottish Independence]]<ref>Henry Thomas Riley, ''Thomae Walsingham, Quondam Monachi S. Albani, Historia Anglicana.'' London: Longman, Green, Longman, Roberts, and Green, 1863, Vol 1. p. 169 [https://books.google.com/books?id=DzI7AQAAMAAJ&dq=tractus%20suspensus%20divisus&pg=PA169#v=onepage&q&f=false] "Deinde tractus, suspensus, et in quartas divisus est; et partes quatuor principalibus civitatibus Angliae sunt transmissae; caput ejus super pontem Londoniarum fixum est, versus partes respiciens Scoticanas."</ref> |- |1326-11-24 ||[[Hugh Despenser the Younger]] || For sodomy. Contemporary accounts differ on whether he died from the full sentence of being hanged, drawn, and quartered. |- | 1381-07-04|| [[Thomas Baker (Peasants' Revolt leader)]] || Aftermath of the 1381 [[Peasants' Revolt]].<ref>Aslet, Clive. "Fobbing" in ''Villages of Britain : The Five Hundred Villages That Made the Countryside.'' Bloomsbury, 2010.</ref><ref>[[Randal Bingley]], ''Fobbing, Life and Landscape'' (Pheon Heritage in association with Thurrock Council Museum, 1997)</ref> |- | 1381-07-15|| [[John Ball (priest)|John Ball]] || Aftermath of the 1381 [[Peasants' Revolt]].<ref>{{Citation | last = Prescott | first = Andrew | title = Ball, John (d. 1381) |subscription=yes | work = Oxford Dictionary of National Biography | publisher = Oxford University Press, hosted at oxforddnb.com | origyear = 2004 | year = 2008 | url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/1214 | accessdate = 22 August 2010 | doi = 10.1093/ref:odnb/1214}}</ref> |- | 1381-1382 || John Buk || Aftermath of the 1381 [[Peasants' Revolt]] <ref>Powell, Edgar (1896). ''The Rising of 1381 in East Anglia.'' Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press. OCLC 1404665. p. 48 [https://hdl.handle.net/2027/yale.39002005399267?urlappend=%3Bseq=64]</ref> |- | 1381-1382 || Richard de Leycester || Aftermath of the 1381 [[Peasants' Revolt]] <ref>Powell, Edgar (1896). ''The Rising of 1381 in East Anglia.'' Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press. OCLC 1404665. p. 48 [https://hdl.handle.net/2027/yale.39002005399267?urlappend=%3Bseq=64]</ref> |- | 1382-05-6 || [[John Wrawe]] || Aftermath of the 1381 [[Peasants' Revolt]] <ref>Powell, Edgar (1896). ''The Rising of 1381 in East Anglia.'' Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press. OCLC 1404665. p. 25 [https://hdl.handle.net/2027/yale.39002005399267?urlappend=%3Bseq=41]</ref> |- | 1388 || [[Thomas Usk]]|| Accused of misleading King Richard <ref>{{Citation | last = Waldron | first = Ronald | title = Usk, Thomas (c.1354–1388) |subscription=yes | work = Oxford Dictionary of National Biography | publisher = Oxford University Press, hosted at oxforddnb.com | origyear = 2004 | year = 2008 | url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/28030 | accessdate = 22 August 2010 | doi = 10.1093/ref:odnb/28030}}</ref> |- | 1401 || [[Llywelyn ap Gruffydd Fychan]] || Allowed [[Owain Glyndŵr]] to escape capture, and therefore disembowelled and dismembered.<ref>{{Citation | last = Steffan | first = Rhobert ap | title = Llywelyn Ap Gruffydd Fychan | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/southwest/sites/llandovery/pages/llywelyn.shtml | publisher = bbc.co.uk | date = 2006 | accessdate = 22 August 2010}}</ref>
|- | 1404 || John Cerle || Killed the [[Thomas of Woodstock, 1st Duke of Gloucester|Duke of Gloucester]] and therefore Johannes Cerle tractus, suspensus, et vivus depositus, et tandem ductus Londoniae tractus ibidem et suspensus demum decollatus est atque in quartas divisus.<ref>Haydon, Frank Scott, 1822-1887. ''Eulogium (historiarum Sive Temporis).'' London: Longman, Brown, Green, Longmans, and Roberts, 1863. Vol 3 p. 402. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Ivs9AAAAcAAJ&dq=tractus%20suspensus%20divisus&pg=PA402#v=onepage&q&f=false]</ref> |- | 1554 || [[Thomas Wyatt the younger]] || Sentenced to be hanged, drawn and quartered for [[Wyatt's rebellion]], but the sentence was commuted to beheading.<ref>{{Citation | last = Hamilton | first = Dakota L. | title = Thomas, William (d. 1554) |subscription=yes | work = Oxford Dictionary of National Biography | publisher = Oxford University Press, hosted at oxforddnb.com | origyear = 2004 | year = 2005 | url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/27242 | accessdate = 20 August 2010 | doi = 10.1093/ref:odnb/27242}}</ref> |- | 1554-05 || [[William Thomas (scholar)]]|| Accused of planning to murder [[Mary I of England]] |- | 1577|| [[Cuthbert Mayne]] || One of the [[Forty Martyrs of England and Wales]] executed under anti-Catholic laws <ref>{{Citation | last = Trudgian | first = Raymond Francis | title = Mayne, Cuthbert <nowiki>[St Cuthbert Mayne]</nowiki> (bap. 1544, d. 1577) |subscription=yes| work = Oxford Dictionary of National Biography | publisher = Oxford University Press, hosted at oxforddnb.com | origyear = 2004 | year = 2008 | url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/18440 | accessdate = 19 August 2010 | doi = 10.1093/ref:odnb/18440}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Graves | first = Michael A. R. | title = Campion, Edmund <nowiki>[St Edmund Campion]</nowiki> (1540–1581) |subscription=yes | work = Oxford Dictionary of National Biography | publisher = Oxford University Press, hosted at oxforddnb.com | origyear = 2004 | year = 2008 | url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/4539 | accessdate = 19 August 2010 | doi = 10.1093/ref:odnb/4539}}</ref> |- | 1577||[[Edmund Campion]]|| One of the [[Forty Martyrs of England and Wales]] executed under anti-Catholic laws <ref>{{Citation | last = Trudgian | first = Raymond Francis | title = Mayne, Cuthbert <nowiki>[St Cuthbert Mayne]</nowiki> (bap. 1544, d. 1577) |subscription=yes| work = Oxford Dictionary of National Biography | publisher = Oxford University Press, hosted at oxforddnb.com | origyear = 2004 | year = 2008 | url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/18440 | accessdate = 19 August 2010 | doi = 10.1093/ref:odnb/18440}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Graves | first = Michael A. R. | title = Campion, Edmund <nowiki>[St Edmund Campion]</nowiki> (1540–1581) |subscription=yes | work = Oxford Dictionary of National Biography | publisher = Oxford University Press, hosted at oxforddnb.com | origyear = 2004 | year = 2008 | url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/4539 | accessdate = 19 August 2010 | doi = 10.1093/ref:odnb/4539}}</ref> |- | 1581-12-01|| [[Alexander Briant]] || Catholic priest, one of the [[Forty Martyrs of England and Wales]]<ref>Simpson, Richard. Edmund Campion: A Biography. New ed., ed., J. Hodges, 1896. p. 457. url= https://hdl.handle.net/2027/uc1.$b55231?urlappend=%3Bseq=471</ref> |- | 1586-09-20|| [[Anthony Babington]] || Executed as one of many involved in the [[Babington plot]]<ref>Francis Edwards, S.J., Plots and plotters in the reign of Elizabeth I. (Dublin: Four Courts, 2002), p. 164.</ref> |- | 1586-09-20|| [[John Ballard (Jesuit)]] || Executed as one of many involved in the [[Babington plot]]<ref>{{Harvnb|Holinshed|1808|pp=915–916}}:{{Quote | John Ballard a preest, and first persuader of Babington to these odious treasons, was laid aloue vpon an hurdell, and six others two and two in like sort, all drawne from Tower hill through the citie of London, untu a field at the vpper end of Holborne, hard by the high waie side to saint Giles in the field, where was erected a scaffold for their execution, and a paire of gallows of extraordinarie hight ... and although the thousands were thought (and indeed so seemed) to be numberlesse: yet somewhat to note the huge multitude, there were by computation able men enow to giue battell to a strong enimie ... On the first daie the traitors were placed vpon the scaffold, that the one might behold the reward of his fellowes treason. Ballard the preest, who was the first brocher of this treason, was the first that was hanged, who being cut downe (according to judgement) was dismembred, his bellie ript up, his bowels and traitorous heart taken out and throwne into the fire, his head also (seuered from his shoulders) was set on a short stake vpon the top of the gallows, and the trunke of his bodie quartered and imbrued in his owne bloud, wherewith the executioners hands were bathed, and some of the standers by (but to their great loathing, as not able for their liues to auoid it, such was the throng) beesprinkled.}}</ref> |- | 1586-09-20 || [[Chidiock Tichborne]]|| Executed as one of many involved in the [[Babington plot]] |- | 1586-09-20 || [[Henry Donn]]|| Executed as one of many involved in the [[Babington plot]] |- | 1586-09-20 || Robert Barnewell || Executed as one of many involved in the [[Babington plot]] |- | 1586-09-20 || John Savage || Executed as one of many involved in the [[Babington plot]] |- | 1586 || Edward Havington || Executed as one of many involved in the [[Babington plot]] Public outcry at the horror of the drawing and quartering of Sept. 20th 1586 caused Elizabeth to order the second group to hang until "quite dead" before disembowelling and quartering.<ref>Francis Edwards, S.J., Plots and plotters in the reign of Elizabeth I. (Dublin: Four Courts, 2002), p. 164.</ref> |- | 1586 || Charles Tilney || Executed as one of many involved in the [[Babington plot]] Hung until "quite dead" before disembowelling and quartering.<ref>Francis Edwards, S.J., Plots and plotters in the reign of Elizabeth I. (Dublin: Four Courts, 2002), p. 164.</ref> |- | 1586 || Edward Jones || Executed as one of many involved in the [[Babington plot]] Hung until "quite dead" before disembowelling and quartering.<ref>Francis Edwards, S.J., Plots and plotters in the reign of Elizabeth I. (Dublin: Four Courts, 2002), p. 164.</ref> |- | 1586 || John Charnock || Executed as one of many involved in the [[Babington plot]] Hung until "quite dead" before disembowelling and quartering.<ref>Francis Edwards, S.J., Plots and plotters in the reign of Elizabeth I. (Dublin: Four Courts, 2002), p. 164.</ref> |- | 1586 || John Travers || Executed as one of many involved in the [[Babington plot]] Hung until "quite dead" before disembowelling and quartering.<ref>Francis Edwards, S.J., Plots and plotters in the reign of Elizabeth I. (Dublin: Four Courts, 2002), p. 164.</ref> |- | 1586 || [[Jerome Bellamy]] || Executed as one of many involved in the [[Babington plot]] Hung until "quite dead" before disembowelling and quartering.<ref>Francis Edwards, S.J., Plots and plotters in the reign of Elizabeth I. (Dublin: Four Courts, 2002), p. 164.</ref> |- | 1586 || [[Robert Gage (MP)|Robert Gage]] || Executed as one of many involved in the [[Babington plot]] Hung until "quite dead" before disembowelling and quartering.<ref>Francis Edwards, S.J., Plots and plotters in the reign of Elizabeth I. (Dublin: Four Courts, 2002), p. 164.</ref> |- | 1594-07-24|| [[John Boste]] || Catholic priest, one of the [[Forty Martyrs of England and Wales]]<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=GyYXAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA63&dq=John+Boste&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjSgs64neTLAhUHPBQKHYKsDaUQ6AEIPzAH#v=onepage&q=John%20Boste&f=false "The Pursuit of John Boste", Catholic Records Society, 1908]</ref>.<ref>[http://www.catholicireland.net/saintoftheday/the-forty-martyrs-of-england-and-wales/ Duffy, Patrick. "The Forty Martyrs of England and Wales", Catholic Ireland]</ref> |- | 1606-01-30 || [[Everard Digby]] || For involvement in [[Gunpowder Plot]] |- | 1606-01-30 ||[[Robert Wintour]] || For involvement in [[Gunpowder Plot]] |- | 1606-01-30 ||[[John_Grant_(Gunpowder_Plot)|John Grant]]|| For involvement in [[Gunpowder Plot]] |- | 1606-01-30 ||[[Thomas Bates]] || For involvement in [[Gunpowder Plot]] |- | 1606-01-31 ||[[Thomas Wintour]] || For involvement in [[Gunpowder Plot]] |- | 1606-01-31 ||[[Ambrose Rookwood]] || For involvement in [[Gunpowder Plot]] |- | 1606-01-31 ||[[Robert Keyes]] || For involvement in [[Gunpowder Plot]] |- | 1606-01-31 ||[[Guy Fawkes]] || For involvement in [[Gunpowder Plot]], but he managed to cheat the executioner by jumping from the scaffold while his head was in the noose, breaking his neck.<ref>{{Harvnb|Northcote Parkinson|1976|pp=91–92}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=283}}</ref> His lifeless body was nevertheless drawn and quartered,<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1973|p=37}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Thompson|2008|p=102}}</ref> and his body parts distributed to "the four corners of the kingdom".<ref>{{citation |title=Guy Fawkes |publisher=York Museums Trust |url=http://www.historyofyork.org.uk//themes/tudor-stuart/guy-fawkes |accessdate=16 May 2010}}</ref> |- | 1628-08-28 ||[[Edmund Arrowsmith]] || Catholic priest, one of the [[Forty Martyrs of England and Wales]]<ref name=odnb>[http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/699 Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]</ref><ref name=CHerald>[http://www.catholicherald.co.uk/spirituallife/saintoftheweek/2010/08/26/the-lancashire-priest-executed-for-his-zeal/ "The Lancaster priest executed for his zeal", Catholic Herald, 26 August 2010]</ref> |- | 1641-09-10 ||[[Ambrose Barlow]] || Catholic priest, one of the [[Forty Martyrs of England and Wales]]<ref name="CammCE">Camm, Bede (1907). [http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/02298b.htm "Ven. Edward Ambrose Barlow"]. ''The Catholic Encyclopedia''. Vol. 2. New York: Robert Appleton. Retrieved 10 September 2013.</ref><ref name = "stambrosebarlow">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Blessed Ambrose Barlow, O.S.B. | work = | publisher = St Ambrose Barlow Website | archivedate = 4 August 2003 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030804214618/http://www.stambrosebarlow.co.uk/visitor/html/ambrose.htm | url =http://www.stambrosebarlow.co.uk/visitor/html/ambrose.htm | doi = | accessdate = 10 September 2013}}</ref> <ref name = "Tyldesley">{{cite web | last = Tyldesley | first = PJ | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Sir Thomas Tyldesley 1612–1651 | work = | publisher = Tyldesley Family History | date = | url = http://www.peterjtyldesley.com/tyldesley/index.html | doi = | accessdate = 2008-12-13}}</ref> |- | 1643-05-30 || [[George Bouchier]] || For his activities in the [[English Civil War]] <ref>{{DNB|wstitle=Bouchier, George |first=Thompson |last=Cooper |volume=6 |page=4}}</ref> |- | 1643-05-30 || [[Robert Yeamans]] || For his activities in the [[English Civil War]] <ref>{{DNB|first=Albert Frederick |last=Pollard |wstitle=Yeamans, Robert |volume=63|page=68}}</ref> |- | 1646-06-30 || [[Philip Powell (martyr)|Philip Powell]] || For being a priest <ref>{{Catholic|wstitle=Ven. Philip Powel}}</ref> |- | 1653 || [[Felim O'Neill of Kinard]] || Executed for his part in the [[Irish Rebellion of 1641]] <ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/northernireland/ashorthistory/archive/intro99.shtml</ref><ref>http://www.libraryireland.com/biography/SirFelimONeill.php</ref> |- | 1654-06-28||[[John Southworth (martyr)|John Southworth]]|| Cromwell ordered that surgeons sew the corpse back together so that it could be sent to [[English College, Douai|Douai College]] for burial.<ref>{{Citation | last = Morrill | first = John | title = Southworth, John <nowiki>[St John Southworth]</nowiki> (1592–1654) |subscription=yes | work = Oxford Dictionary of National Biography | publisher = Oxford University Press, hosted at oxforddnb.com | year = 2004 | url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/67460 | accessdate = 19 August 2010 | doi = 10.1093/ref:odnb/67460}}</ref> |- | 1658-07-07 || [[Edward Ashton (colonel)]] || For the plot against [[Oliver Cromwell|the Lord Protector]] set on foot by agents of [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] in 1658, and for complicity in which [[Sir Henry Slingsby]] and John Hewet were executed. <ref>{{Cite DNB|wstitle=Ashton, Edward|volume=2}}</ref> |- | 1663 ||Thomas Oates ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]]<ref>Drake, Francis''. Eboracum : Or, the History and Antiquities of the City of York, from Its Origin to This Time. Together with an Account of the Ainsty, or County of the Same, and a Description and History of the Cathedral Church, from Its First Foundation to the Present Year. Illustrated with Seventeen Copper-Plates. in Two Volumes''. Printed for T. Wilson and R. Spence, High-Ousegate, 1788, vol 1. p. 60. [https://books.google.com/books?id=WmVZAAAAYAAJ&vq=farnley&pg=PA175#v=onepage&q&f=false] </ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Hopper | first = Andrew | title = The Farnley Wood Plot and the Memory of the Civil Wars in Yorkshire |subscription=yes | publisher = Cambridge University Press, hosted at jstor.org | journal = The Historical Journal | volume = 45 | date = June 2002 | pages = 281, 296–297 | jstor = 3133646 | issue = 2 | doi=10.1017/s0018246x02002406}}</ref> |- | 1663 ||Samuel Ellis ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||John Nettleton, sr.||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||John Nettleton, jr. ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||Robert Scott ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||William Tolson ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||John Forster ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||Robert Olroyd ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 || John Asquith ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||Peregrine Corney||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||John Snowden||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||John Smith ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||William Ash||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 || John Errington ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||Robert Atkins ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 || William Colton ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||George Denham ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||Henry Watson ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||Richard Wilson ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||Ralph Rymer ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1663 ||Charles Carre ||Executed for participating in the [[Farnley Wood Plot]] |- | 1685 || over 200 || Charged with treason following the [[Monmouth Rebellion]], their remains were parboiled, tarred, and displayed on poles, trees and lampposts; only when James conducted a [[royal progress|progress]] through the area were they removed and buried.<ref>{{Harvnb|Zook|1999|p=141}}</ref> |- | 1788-02-16 || Robert Keon || hanged, drawn, and quartered for murder in a private quarrel <ref>James Kelly "'That Damn'd Thing Called Honour'" Cork University Press 1995 pp194-196</ref> |- |1803-09-20 || [[Robert Emmet]] || convicted of high treason in the [[Irish Rebellion of 1803]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Brooke-Tyrrell | first1 = Alma | last2 = | first2 = | year = 1983 | title = Focus on Thomas Street | journal = Dublin Historical Record | volume = 36 | issue = 3 | pages = 107–117 | publisher = | jstor = 30100607 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Dawson | first1 = T. | last2 = | first2 = | year = 1971 | title = Between the Steps | journal = Dublin Historical Record | volume = 24 | issue = 3 | pages = 65–75 | publisher = | jstor = 30103977 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=1A5AAAAAYAAJ&pg=PT560&lpg=PT560&dq=robert+emmet+treason#v=onepage&q=robert%20emmet%20treason&f=false | title = Cobbett's complete collection of state trials and From the ninth year of the reign of King Henry, the Second, A.D.1163, to ... \George IV, A.D.1820] | author1 = Cobbett | first1 = William | last2 = Jardine | first2 = David | year = 1820}}</ref> He was hanged and then beheaded once dead.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://homepage.tinet.ie/~seanjmurphy/irhismys/emmet.htm|title=Irish Historical Mysteries: The Grave of Robert Emmet|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref> |}
